Header: President inaugurates Fourth sessions of the Eighth Parliament a simple yet dignified manner
Content: The fourth sessions of the Eighth Parliament was inaugurated this morning by President Gotabhaya Rajapaksa in a simple yet dignified manner. The President said that the independence of the country would not be compromised and the Constitution should be changed for the security of the country. The President further stated that Parliament should be made an exemplary venue for the realization of the issues of the masses and the discussion of national policy. President had given instructions not to carry out the traditional convoys and 21-gun-salutes in order to make the ceremony simpler. Thus the inauguration of the fourth sessions of the eighth Parliament became one of the most import sessions in the history. A group of more than 600 invitees joined in the event. It was the Speaker Karu Jayasuriya who first arrived for the fourth sessions of the eight Parliament. Thereafter Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa arrived at the Parliamentary complex. They were followed by President Gotabhaya Rajapaksa and the First Lady. Speaker Karu Jayasuriya, Parliamentary Secretary General Dhammika Dassanayake and Sergeant at Arms Narendra Fernando greeted the President. Thereafter the Jayamangala Gatha was sung showering blessings. It was rendered by students of Kotte Ananda Balika Vidyalaya. After the Sergeant-at-Arms announced the Presidentâ€™s arrival in Parliament, the Chief Sergeant-at-Arms brought the Mace to the Parliamentary Complex. It was thereafter President Gotabhaya Rajapaksa who arrived in the Chamber. A special allocation of seats was made within the Parliament.Although previously, the Speaker was given a prominent seat, this time the President took a special seat above the Speaker. The President presented his manifesto, the vision of prosperity in Parliament instead of the Throne Speech.
